moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4
comment:
(Designed to prevent the ...g5 break so common in the 08/g3 main lines, or so
I read from my books!)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5
comment: (Against Paul McDonald in Section 'A' Alan played the alternative 11...Be7.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6
comment: # (The line that I was following continued

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7
comment:
(Also planning to sacrifice on e5, but to recapture with the queen after d4xe5,
but...)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2
comment:
(Pinning the ...Nc6 to the ...Qc7, and also threatening
17.Bxh7+, thus effectively, if Black played 16...Ndxe5 although he is still
disolving the White centre, he will have a 2 pawn defecite, not just 1!)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2 h6
comment: ("Chickening out" of liquidating the centre under my terms.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2 h6 17. Kg3
comment:
(Now the Nf3 is no longer pinned to the White King. the exchange sacrifice on
e5 is now impossible.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2 h6 17. Kg3 b5
comment:
(A weakening move, trying to connect his
Rooks with a subsequent ...Bb7, but this Bishop's power is blunted by it's own
prawns!)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2 h6 17. Kg3 b5 18. Nh3 Rd8 19. Rac1 Bb7 20. Bh7+ Kh8 21. Nf4 Nf8 22. Ng6+ Nxg6 23. Bxg6
comment:
#(I origionally intended playing 23.Qxg6 with what I thought was a
winning plan involving 24.Ng5, but 23...Rf8! 24.Ng5 Rf6! exploiting the
prawn's enpinment on the White king, rathet scuppers my plans.)

moves: 1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 Nf6 4. e5 Nfd7 5. f4 c5 6. c3 Nc6 7. Ndf3 Qb6 8. h4 cxd4 9. cxd4 Bb4+ 10. Kf2 f6 11. Be3 fxe5 12. fxe5 O-O 13. a3 Be7 14. b4 a6 15. Bd3 Qc7 16. Qc2 h6 17. Kg3 b5 18. comment:
(Resigns 0 1!! Not bad for my first shot at the White side  of the French
Tarrach eh? My annalysis now runs)
